content:
Just got this for the first time today. :)
Took me about 7 minutes to solve in Reverse mode, but was so fun.

The hard part was debugging why my 'transpose' wasn't working and how the row size had somehow changed (it was the '-' sign from going less than zero or > 9).

It's hard to solve in Reverse because of the %10 part, but once you realise it, it's easy to fix. :)

Unfortunately only one other clasher managed to solve it in time (a couple gave up immediately):
https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/4204128c60a1e48ab7812a029793ad184c02dc5

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's unusual, needs some thinking, but is solvable in 5minutes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: elle resouds parfaitement l enigme

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: While this is an interesting concept, I doubt people would be able to solve this in 15 minutes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a pretty interesting clash. Looks good to me and although this is nontrivial, it is still solvable in five minutes.

First of all, it's an interesting concept.

You need to specify in the Constraints section that there is exactly one solution. This is because there are arrangements of digits and x's such that there is no solution and arrangements where there is more than one solution. In particular, if an x is sandwiched between two numbers, that x may be filled with two digits, e.g. 4x0 → 420 / 470.

Goal section
* Suggest to change the first paragraph as follows:

In a 4x4 grid with digits and one or more {{x}}, fill every {{x}} based on the digits adjacent to it, so that
• all horizontally adjacent digits in the same row form a linear range of numbers, and
• all vertically adjacent digits in the same column form a linear range of numbers.

The common difference in each linear range of numbers may be any integer. For example, {{34x}} becomes {{345}} and {{x35}} becomes {{135}}.

Thanks.
Done, thanks for the usual good suggestions.
Good point, I've added it to the constraints. Thanks!

Thanks for the feedback. I thought that once the idea is clear, coding the solution should not take too many minutes (it's not difficult to calculate x in [3 4 x], neither is it difficult in [x 2 4]; this puzzle *just* combines that a bit horizontally and vertically). I might however overlook how much minutes I subconsciously spent while designing this Clash, so that I lost feeling with how much minutes it takes for someone seeing this Clash for the first time, like during actual COC play.

I've no clear idea on how to alter this clash to make it easier (and it's definitely too easy for an easy Classic Puzzle), so I'll leave it hanging here for a bit longer and just remove it if it does not get the approval or more disapproval in the coming days.
Je ne parle pas francais, mais merci.

It seems you are talking about another clash. Do you maybe mean the following clash: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/588226510aeded4373bba5958676113f5b900

And if indeed you talked about that one: nice that you liked it, I found that one pretty cool myself. Only I am curious what you meant with the %10 part. Or maybe you are talking about another clash alltogether.

No, I mean this one. :)
The %10 part is about how it cycles back to 0 after 9 or to 9 for -1.

Maybe you thought it wasn't this one because of my mention of the row size changing, but I just meant that my code's rows were changing size before I realised the %10 thing because "048x"-> "04812" which then ruins my square grid and makes transpose not work.

Ah my mistake, I totally forgot that in this one I had included the %10. Looking now to my solution code I can imagine quite some people passing. I make some of my clashes just for the few admirers like you ;-).

Yeah, it is not an easy one in a lot of languages. I really enjoy clashes where Ruby is able to outperform other languages with its stdlib. Having ".transpose" and RegEx ".gsub" as built-ins really make this a lot easier to solve.
